reviewText: Do you know what peeves me? -  when we finally get Ray "Darth Maul" Park and ex-Power Rangers Johnny Yong and Dan Southworth together in the same film and it's a bad one. Not just bad in a general way, but in a bad-even-for-DTV-cinema kind of way. When three stuntmen team up to make a movie that's one-half religious thriller and one-half "Sin City"-ripoff, watch out: it doesn't matter who they've got starring in it because it's still going to stink. Okay, I don't want to be prejudiced against stuntmen, but directors Mitch Gould, Hiro Koda, and David Wald got so carried away with the ultimately dumb storyline that they failed to maximize their resources and delivered subpar results for a movie that could've been off-the-charts cool.The story: a soulless hitman (Park,Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace), a mystical assassin descended from an ancient line (Yong, the 2nd Black Ranger), and the last remaining Templar knight (Esteban Cueto,Undisputed III: Redemption) come together in Los Angeles to stop the many-bodied Legion (headed by Richard Cetrone,Ghosts of Mars) from opening a portal to hell to summon a demon army for world domination.It was only after I had watched the movie and looked up the official synopsis that I understood the plot - an exercise in convolution. You see, not only do we have the Legion thing going on, but there's also the matter of Beelzebub (Steve Fite) being betrayed by Legion, the mystical assassin being torn between two mentors (Gerald Okamura and Rikio Nakashita), the whole issue of Ray Park's hitman character not having a soul and being torn between something or other... Oh, and also Park's attempt at comic relief, which are as unfathomable as any twist in the storyline. Nevertheless, writer Mitch Gould obviously felt the plot was strong enough to have it be the prominent feature of the movie - stressing utterly boring dialogue scenes over potential action spectacles.The key word here is "potential", seeing as the action scenes are good at best but never rise about anything else on the DTV market. Appeasingly, Johnny Yong and lead henchman Dan Southworth (the Quantum Ranger) engage in a couple fast-paced swordfights to see who is the superior Ranger, but even though Yong gets a few other nice encounters of his own, these are the exception since the rest of the limited fight scenes stink. I don't know whose decision it was that Ray Park should be limited to mere gunfights, but it's a damning one; you'd think that Ray would get to turn at least one cartwheel or throw a single kick, but no - it's CGI-mucked gunplay all the way. Esteban Cueto plays a brawler role during these fights, meaning nothing he does is worth watching; you've seen it all before. Combine that with a limited number of boring sets and some lackluster computer imagery - including a laughable diorama of hell - and you're left with a film that's all but completely dull to look at.I won't even get into the acting content, but rest assured, low standards are a requirement. Again, this movie really isn't great: while it's nice to see Johnny Yong in one of his few action-oriented roles since he quit the Power Rangers, neither he nor any of the other bankable stars are used to their full potential (this includes Derek Mears, the latest Jason Voorhees, in a cameo). A "comic book movie" with a religious storyline and martial arts action probably sounded great during its conceptual period, but in practice, very little of what the film attempts does it do right. It's hard for me to recommend this movie to anybody besides fans of the ex-Rangers or anybody who wants to see Ray Park without heavy makeup, so unless you're sure that you fall into either of those groups, don't bother.
summary: "He was a fool!" - "But a noble one"

reviewText: This movie is hilarious, full of action, and full of gore.  Everyone's attacking everyone else for dumb reasons, the big guy is swinging a metal conduit as some possessed people, and some weird (but valid) templar mythology intermixed in one comic book movie stew.The acting is awful but it's a b-movie.  Definitely watchable.

reviewText: Ray Park is one of the most talented martial artists in movies today and guess what?.......he doesn't do anything but fire pistols in this horrible crap pile of a movie.  Zero plot, horrible acting, putrid choreography and awful production values.  There is nothing even remotely redeeming about this waste of money.  If you have a brain you will avoid this at all costs.

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: The film uses cartoon boxes and subscripts to give you that animated superhero/grindhouse feel to the film, but fails to achieve that goal by the lack of graphic violence, being light on blood and babes. The film opens with the fighting and burial of the demon "Legion" in the desert. It then moves into three quick subplots. Max (ray Park) is an English accent mercenary leading a killing team in Los Angeles. He has a big gig coming up. In a major plot point we discover he had been dead for 20 minutes before recovering. The second subplot involves Ninja assassin Ryu (Johnny Yong Bosch) also operating in LA. The third subplot is Cain (Esteban Cueto) not to be confused with the Seagal character Kane. They are both big lumbering individuals who use the slow motion one punch technique. Cain, a Night Templar who has aged gracefully, also is a master of ancient weapons such as conduit.The three come together and must fight Legion and his minions before he can open the gates of one of the kingdoms of hell and release millions of demons into LA, as if we would notice. The catch is, once a demon is killed, it can enter a new soul and turn an innocent into another killing demon.The film started out good, but then the plot become disjointed. They needed to make one of the big three a woman. Max had good lines which gave us some comic relief. The other two characters couldn't deliver their lines and bored me to tears. Part of a Walmart 10 pack.Parental Guide: F-bomb. No sex or nudity.
Title: N/A
